titlestmt.titleproper: Rockefeller (Nelson A.) Vice Presidential records, Secretariat, Weekly Briefing Notes, Series 14
A Guide to the Nelson A. Rockefeller Vice Presidential records, Secretariat, Weekly Briefing Notes, Series 14 FA261
titlestmt.author: Kathleen Leonard

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-02-17 10:44:31 -0500.

did.unittitle: Nelson A. Rockefeller Vice Presidential records, Secretariat, Weekly Briefing Notes, Series 14

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: President Gerald R. Ford nominated Nelson A. Rockefeller to fill the vacant vice presidency following the resignation of President Richard M. Nixon in August 1974. Rockefeller served as Vice President from December 19, 1974, to January 20, 1977.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Weekly Briefing Notes on U.S. Domestic Development series consists of statistics generated each week for President Gerald Ford and Vice President Nelson Rockefeller by the U.S. Bureau of the Census and Statistical Policy Division of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) from May 1975 to January 1977. Vincent P. Barabba was Director of the Bureau of the Census and Joseph W. Duncan was Deputy Associate Director of the Statistical Policy Division for the OMB. In September 1976, Robert L. Hagan became Acting Director of the Bureau of the Census.

These statistical reports are organized into the following sections: Section A: General Economic Indicators, Section B: General Social Indicators and Socioeconomic Series, Section C: Government Activity, and Section D: Environment, Science, and Culture. (In Box 1, Section C is Health, Education, and Welfare and Section D is Government Activity.) Section E: Selected Subjects appears occasionally throughout the series with statistics on specific topics. The statistics that appear in each report are highlighted in yellow through the table of contents. The reports include multicolored graphics with brief summaries.

Most folders contain a weekly chartbook detailing the frequency of each section of statistical data along with its appearance in the weekly briefing notes through the entire year. For example, Section A, National Income and Product, Gross National Product is followed by the dates it appears in the briefing notes.

Some folders starting in Box 2 contain a short memo from Vice President Rockefeller to President Ford about the highlights in each weekly briefing notes report. Richard Allison, a member of the Vice President's staff, wrote the memos found at the end of Box 3.
Briefing notes organized by subject (special reports), such as healthcare, housing, crime and criminal justice, appear at the end of the series in Box 8.
